body: Some of the pieces of adventuring gear found on Table: Goods and Services are described below, along with any special benefits they confer on the user (“you”).
name: Adventuring Gear

sections.body: This leather knapsack has one large pocket that closes with a buckled strap and holds about 2 cubic feet of material. Some may have one or more smaller pockets on the sides.
sections.name: Backpack

sections.body: This is a sturdy wooden barrel with a tight-fitting lid, banded with metal.
sections.name: Barrel

sections.body: This large basket has a lid and holds about 2 cubic feet.
sections.name: Basket

sections.body: This consists of two woolen sheets sewn together along the bottom and one side to create a bag for sleeping in. Some have cloth straps along the open side so the bedroll can be tied closed while you are sleeping. It can be rolled and tied into a tight coil for storage or transport. Most people use a blanket with the bedroll to stay warm or provide a ground cushion.
sections.name: Bedroll

sections.body: This handbell can produce only one loud note.
sections.name: Bell

sections.body: A typical leather or cloth belt pouch has a leather cord to cinch it shut and another to tie it to your belt. It is large enough to hold 100–200 coins or two apples.
sections.name: Belt Pouch
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Belt Pouch

sections.body: This warm, woven blanket has straps so it can be rolled up and tied. Blankets are often used in conjunction with bedrolls to provide additional warmth or a ground cushion.
sections.name: Blanket

sections.body: Whether it is used to hoist treasure from a pit or move supplies, a simple block-and-tackle pulley, when it is properly secured, adds a +5 circumstance bonus on Strength checks to lift heavy objects. Securing the pulley requires 1 minute.
sections.name: Block and Tackle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Block and Tackle

sections.body: This glass bottle holds about a pint and includes a cork.
sections.name: Bottle

sections.body: A typical bucket has a rope handle and can hold 1–2 gallons of liquid.
sections.name: Bucket

sections.body:
A caltrop is a four-pronged metal spike crafted so that one prong faces up no matter how the caltrop comes to rest. You scatter caltrops on the ground in the hope that your enemies step on them or are at least forced to slow down to avoid them. One 2-pound bag of caltrops covers an area 5 feet square.

Each time a creature moves into an area covered by caltrops (or spends a round fighting while standing in such an area), it runs the risk of stepping on one. Make an attack roll for the caltrops (base attack bonus +0) against the creature. For this attack, the creature's shield, armor, and deflection bonuses do not count. If the creature is wearing shoes or other footwear, it gets a +2 armor bonus to AC. If the attack succeeds, the creature has stepped on a caltrop. The caltrop deals 1 point of damage, and the creature's speed is reduced by half because its foot is wounded. This movement penalty lasts for 24 hours, until the creature is successfully treated with a DC 15 Heal check, or until it receives at least 1 point of magical healing. A charging or running creature must immediately stop if it steps on a caltrop. Any creature moving at half speed or slower can pick its way through a bed of caltrops with no trouble.

Caltrops may not work against unusual opponents.
sections.name: Caltrops

sections.body: A candle dimly illuminates a small area, increasing the light level in a 5-foot radius by one step (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A candle cannot increase the light level above normal light. A candle burns for 1 hour.
sections.name: Candle

sections.body: This square yard of heavy cloth is suitable for painting, for covering items in a rainstorm, for creating a sail, or as an improvised bag. It is not waterproof but can be treated with oil, wax, or resin to make it water-resistant.
sections.name: Canvas

sections.body: Chain has hardness 10 and 5 hit points. It can be burst with a DC 26 Strength check.
sections.name: Chain

sections.body: This fat piece of white chalk easily marks wood, metal, or stone. You can write with it for about 24 hours before it is expended. Chalk also comes in other colors, but these are rarer and can be more expensive.
sections.name: Chalk

sections.body: A common small wooden chest (2 cubic feet, 1 hit point, break DC 17). Most include a simple inset lock.
sections.name: Chest

sections.body: A crowbar grants a +2 circumstance bonus on Strength checks made to force open a door or chest. If used in combat, treat a crowbar as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a club of its size.
sections.name: Crowbar

sections.body: This bundle of dry wood includes twigs and logs.
sections.name: Firewood

sections.body: This metal hook is little more than a stiff, bent needle.
sections.name: Fishhook

sections.body: This net measures 5 feet by 5 feet, and can be used to cover a pit or to block Tiny or larger creatures from entering an area.
sections.name: Fishing Net
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Fishing Net

sections.body: This glass bottle holds 1 pint. It is relatively fragile and breaks if thrown at a creature or hard surface. Flasks may be simple blown glass, or they may be elaborate affairs embossed with family crests and other artwork.
sections.name: Flask

sections.body: Lighting a torch with flint and steel is a full-round action, and lighting any other fire with them takes at least that long.
sections.name: Flint and Steel
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Flint and Steel

sections.body: Throwing a grappling hook requires a ranged attack roll, treating the hook as a thrown weapon with a range increment of 10 feet. Objects with ample places to catch the hook are AC 5.
sections.name: Grappling Hook
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Grappling Hook

sections.body: If a hammer is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a spiked gauntlet of its size.
sections.name: Hammer

sections.body: The standard hourglass takes 1 hour to empty the sand from the upper chamber.
sections.name: Hourglass

sections.body: Ink in colors other than black costs twice as much.
sections.name: Ink

sections.body: This is a wooden stylus with a metal tip that retains a small amount of ink after you dip it in a vial of ink.
sections.name: Inkpen

sections.body: This basic jug is fitted with a stopper and holds 1 gallon of liquid.
sections.name: Jug, Clay

sections.body: This simple 10-foot ladder consists of two long boards with wooden steps nailed into them at 1-foot increments.
sections.name: Ladder

sections.body: A lamp illuminates a small area, providing normal light in a 15-foot radius and increasing the light level by one step for an additional 15 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A lamp does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. A lamp burns for 6 hours on one pint of oil. You can carry a lamp in one hand.
sections.name: Lamp, Common

sections.body: A bullseye lantern provides normal light in a 60-foot cone and increases the light level by one step in the area beyond that, out to a 120-foot cone (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A bullseye lantern does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. A lantern burns for 6 hours on one pint of oil. You can carry a lantern in one hand.
sections.name: Lantern, Bullseye

sections.body: A hooded lantern sheds normal light in a 30-foot radius and increases the light level by one step for an additional 30 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A hooded lantern does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. A lantern burns for 6 hours on one pint of oil. You can carry a lantern in one hand.
sections.name: Lantern, Hooded

sections.body: The DC to open a lock with the Disable Device skill depends on the lock's quality: simple (DC 20), average (DC 25), good (DC 30), or superior (DC 40).
sections.name: Lock

sections.body:
Manacles can bind a Medium creature. A manacled creature can use the Escape Artist skill to slip free (DC 30, or DC 35 for masterwork manacles). Breaking the manacles requires a Strength check (DC 26, or DC 28 for masterwork manacles). Manacles have hardness 10 and 10 hit points.

Most manacles have locks; add the cost of the lock you want to the cost of the manacles.

For the same cost, you can buy manacles for a Small creature. For a Large creature, manacles cost 10 times the indicated amount, and for a Huge creature, 100 times the indicated amount. Gargantuan, Colossal, Tiny, Diminutive, and Fine creatures can be held only by specially made manacles, which cost at least 100 times the indicated amount.
sections.name: Manacles, Standard and Masterwork
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Manacles/Standard and Masterwork

sections.body: This hand-held mirror is about a foot across. Unlike many higher-quality glass mirrors, this one is made out of polished steel and sturdy enough that you can drop it without risk of breakage.
sections.name: Mirror

sections.body: Whether it is a simple pottery cup or an elaborate drinking stein with a handle and decorative lid that flips up, this cup may be used to hold any sort of beverage. Tankards are commonly made out of clay or tin.
sections.name: Mug/Tankard

sections.body:
A pint of oil burns for 6 hours in a lantern or lamp. You can also use a flask of oil as a splash weapon. Use the rules for alchemist's fire (see Special Substances and Items on Table: Goods and Services), except that it takes a full-round action to prepare a flask with a fuse. Once it is thrown, there is a 50% chance of the flask igniting successfully.

You can pour a pint of oil on the ground to cover an area 5 feet square, provided that the surface is smooth. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 1d3 points of fire damage to each creature in the area.
sections.name: Oil

sections.body: This sheet of thin, treated animal skin is a durable writing surface and is suitable for making magic scrolls. It has hardness 0, 2 hit points, and a break DC of 5.
sections.name: Parchment

sections.body: A sheet of ordinary paper typically measures 9 inches by 6 inches and is unsuitable for making magical scrolls. It has hardness 0, 1 hit point, and a break DC of 5.
sections.name: Paper

sections.body: If a miner's pick is used in combat, treat it as a two-handed improvised weapon that deals piercing damage equal to that of a heavy pick of its size.
sections.name: Pick, Miner's

sections.body: This basic clay pitcher has a handle and an open top with a groove for easy pouring. It holds 1/2 gallon of liquid. The listed weight is for a pitcher filled with water, wine, or ale; empty, it weighs about 1/2 pound.
sections.name: Pitcher

sections.body: A piton is an iron spike with a loop or ring on the end so you can tie a rope to it.
sections.name: Piton

sections.body: This 10-foot length of wood is useful for probing pits, flagstones, and murky liquids from a safe distance.
sections.name: Pole

sections.body: This 8-inch-diameter iron pot is sturdy and has feet, a lid, and a rounded handle. It can hold enough stew to feed one hungry human for one meal. A mithral pot is lighter and food rarely sticks to it.
sections.name: Pot

sections.body: This iron-shod wooden beam gives you a +2 circumstance bonus on Strength checks made to break open a door and allows a second person to help, automatically increasing your bonus by 2.
sections.name: Ram, Portable

sections.body: This rope has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 23 Strength check.
sections.name: Rope, Hemp

sections.body: This rope has 4 hit points and can be burst with a DC 24 Strength check.
sections.name: Rope, Silk

sections.body: This heavy canvas sack, useful for carrying adventuring gear and other supplies, holds about 4 cubic feet. A leather thong threaded through loops at the bag's end allows it to be tied shut easily.
sections.name: Sack

sections.body: A leather or wooden scroll case easily holds four scrolls; you can cram more inside, but retrieving any of them becomes a full-round action rather than a move action. You must destroy the scroll case to damage its contents (hardness 2 for leather or 5 for wood, 2 hit points, break DC 15). A scroll case is not watertight, and must still be protected from the elements.
sections.name: Scroll Case
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Scroll Case

sections.body: This stick of red wax is used to seal envelopes, often using an impression from a signet ring as proof they were sent by you.
sections.name: Sealing Wax
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Sealing Wax

sections.body: This needle allows you to stitch together cloth, canvas, or thin leather.
sections.name: Sewing Needle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Sewing Needle

sections.body: If a shovel is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a club of its size.
sections.name: Shovel

sections.body: With a DC 5 Perform (wind instruments) check, you can use a whistle to signal the same sorts of situations as signal horns. A whistle's piercing report can be clearly heard (Perception DC 0) up to a quarter-mile away. For each quarter-mile beyond, Perception checks to hear a whistle take a –2 penalty. Silent whistles that only animals and other creatures with keen hearing can hear also exist.
sections.name: Signal Whistle
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Signal Whistle

sections.body: This ring has an embossed design, typically a family crest or official icon. You press a signet ring into softened wax to leave an impression of this symbol.
sections.name: Signet Ring
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Signet Ring

sections.body: This heavy, two-handed hammer is normally used in carpentry and other construction tasks, and is also useful for driving in tent stakes to help secure campsites in areas with strong winds. If used in combat, treat it as an improvised earth breaker (see page 27).
sections.name: Sledge

sections.body: Most soap is made from animal fat and lye derived from ashes. You can use this thick block of soap to scrub clothes, pots, linens, adventurers, or anything else that might be dirty. A bar of soap has approximately 50 uses.
sections.name: Soap

sections.body: Objects viewed through a spyglass are magnified to twice their size. Characters using a spyglass take a –1 penalty on Perception skill checks per 20 feet of distance to the target, if the target is visible.
sections.name: Spyglass

sections.body: A small tents. Holds one Medium creature and takes 20 minutes to assemble. Packing up a tent takes half as long as assembling it.
sections.name: Tent

sections.body: A torch burns for 1 hour, shedding normal light in a 20-foot radius and increasing the light level by one step for an additional 20 feet beyond that area (darkness becomes dim light and dim light becomes normal light). A torch does not increase the light level in normal light or bright light. If a torch is used in combat, treat it as a one-handed improvised weapon that deals bludgeoning damage equal to that of a gauntlet of its size, plus 1 point of fire damage.
sections.name: Torch

sections.body: The listed price is for a day's worth of food. This bland food is usually some kind of hard tack, jerky, and dried fruit, though the contents vary from region to region and the race of those creating it. As long as it stays dry, it can go for months without spoiling.
sections.name: Trail Rations
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Trail Rations

sections.body: A vial is made out of glass or steel and holds 1 ounce of liquid.
sections.name: Vial

sections.body: This large, bulky contrivance gives the time accurately to within half an hour per day since it was last set. It requires a source of water, and it must be kept still because it marks time by the regulated flow of droplets of water.
sections.name: Water Clock
sections.url: pfsrd://Core Rulebook/Rules/Equipment/Goods And Services/Adventuring Gear/Water Clock

sections.body: This bag is made of an animal bladder or treated leather. It is watertight and holds about 1/2 gallon of liquid. The listed weight is for a waterskin full of water; empty, it weighs about 2 pounds.
sections.name: Waterskin

sections.body: A whetstone allows you to sharpen a blade by sliding it against the stone at a precise angle. Honing a blade with a whetstone requires about 15 minutes of work and grants the weapon a +1 bonus on your damage roll the first time you hit with it. This only works on nonmagical blades.
sections.name: Whetstone
